questions.question: What is the role of inhibin?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inhibits the secretion of FSH Explanation: Inhibin from the granulosa cells inhibits FSH secretion. It is a hormone primarily produced by the ovaries (in females) and testes (in males). It regulates the reproductive system by inhibiting the secretion of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) from the anterior pituitary gland. Inhibin suppresses the FSH Inhibin B: Before ovulation Inhibin A: After ovulation Stimulates the secretion of FSH (Option A): Inhibin does not stimulate FSH release; instead, it inhibits it. FSH is involved in the growth and maturation of reproductive cells, but inhibin reduces its secretion once the follicle or sperm production reaches sufficient levels. Inhibition of PRL (Option C) and Stimulation of PRL (Option D): Inhibin does not directly regulate prolactin (PRL), a hormone involved in milk production. PRL levels are primarily controlled by dopamine from the hypothalamus and other factors, not by inhibin. Therefore, inhibin neither inhibits nor stimulates PRL production. Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, pg 401-403.

questions.question: In the cervical smear below, which of the following stains are used
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Papanicolaou stain Explanation: Papanicolaou stain is the standard stain used in cervical smears to detect cellular abnormalities. The Pap stain results in: Well-stained nuclear chromatin Differential polychromatic counterstaining of the cytoplasm Cytoplasmic transparency H & E stain (Option B) ( hematoxylin and eosin) staining procedure uses two dyes to stain tissue samples, making it easier to see cell structure under a microscope; this is commonly used for histopathological tissue sections , not for cervical smears. Giemsa stain (Option C) is used to stain blood and bone marrow smears, as well as some parasites, but it is not used in cervical cytology. Toluidine blue (Option D) is a basic metachromatic dye primarily used to stain acidic components of tissues, such as nucleic acids and mast cell granules. It is not used for routine cervical cytology.

questions.question: Which of the following tumour markers are positive for seminoma? PLAP OCT3/4 NANOG HCG
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Seminomas are characterized by specific tumour markers like PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase) HCG LDH Newer markers: OCT Â¾ NANOG CD117 SALL4 Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis. A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma , and germinoma is present in the pineal gland . Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade. Gross: Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis . Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 969, 970

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is NOT caused by high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV)?
questions.explanation: serotypes are known to cause condyloma acuminatum and are commonly associated with laryngeal lesions, particularly in children and young adults Types of HPV Cutaneous involvement HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk) Filiform wart Verruca Plantaris HPV 5, 8 (high risk) Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis Mucosal involvement HPV 6, 11 (low risk) Condyloma Acuminatum Recurrent laryngeal papillomas HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk) Squamous cell carcinoma HPV 16 ( High risk) LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix Vulval carcinoma Oropharyngeal SCC HPV 18 ( High risk) LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix Anogenital carcinoma Cutaneous involvement Benign Warts Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris) : Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57). Flat Warts (Verruca Plana) : Also prevalent among children. Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris) : Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1 ). Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas. Associated with serotypes 5, 8 , 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47. Mucosal involvement Anogenital Warts It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum. A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11. Head and Neck Lesions Benign : Recurrent laryngeal papillomas , especially in children (serotypes 6, 11 ). Malignant : Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18 ) Carcinoma Cervix Mainly squamous cell carcinoma , linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others . Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.question: What is the most probable tumour that a 22-year-old woman with a sizable growth in her right ovary, which has been determined to originate from all three germ layers based on histopathology, is experiencing?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Teratoma Explanation: Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries. They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers. Immature teratoma: Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage. They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary. They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy. They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components). Mature teratoma Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts , are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases. They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma. Grossly, they are unilocular cysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands. Monodermal teratoma: Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy. Dysgerminoma (Option A) is also a type of germ cell tumour (GCT) that typically secretes beta hCG. Thecoma (Option C) is a rare benign tumour originating from the ovarian stroma, accounting for less than 1% of all ovarian tumours. It is most commonly found in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women. Theca lutein cysts (Option D) are rare benign cystic lesions caused by hypertrophy of the theca interna layer due to excessive stimulation by hCG.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 48-year-old patient who came with scrotal swelling, had elevated LDH levels but normal AFP levels on tests for testicular tumours, and exhibited a specific histological picture after orchidectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Seminoma Explanation: The clinical presentation and histopathological findings suggest testicular seminoma. Seminomas elevate LDH levels, while AFP remains normal. Histology shows large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. Seminoma: It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis. A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma , and germinoma is present in the pineal gland . Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade. Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG. Morphology: Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis . Histology of seminoma: Sheets of monomorphic cells. The sheets are divided into poorly demarcated lobules by the septa of the fibrous tissue. The septa show lymphocytic infiltration (T lymphocytes). The classic seminoma cell is large and round to polyhedral with a distinct cell membrane and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli. The cytoplasm is clear or watery appearing and contains glycogen . The arrows in the image below show seminomatous tumour cells. Source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Testis_seminoma_3.jpg Testicular Tumour Corresponding Tumor Markers Seminoma Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) HCG LDH Newer markers: Oct 3/4, Nanog, CD117, SALL4 Embryonal Carcinoma CD-30 Yolk sac tumour Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Alpha-1 antitrypsin Choriocarcinoma Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin ( Î² -hCG) Teratoma Cytokeratin

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Meigs syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Dysgerminoma of the ovary Explanation: Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumour and is not part of Meigs syndrome. Meigs Syndrome: Meigs syndrome is a condition characterised by a triad of: Ovarian fibroma (fibrothecoma) Ascites Hydrothorax (pleural effusion)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning liquid-based cytology?

options.C: Study of fluid in the tumor microenvironment

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Urine specimen is used Explanation: Liquid-based cytology is often used to collect specimens, including urine, and study cells for various diagnostic purposes. Liquid-based cytology: It is a technique to collect and prepare cell samples for microscopic analysis. It involves gathering cells from various body fluids, such as cervical or vaginal fluids, respiratory secretions, or urine, depending on the diagnostic goal. This method is commonly used for cervical cancer screening. Cells collected from the cervix with a brush or spatula are suspended in a preservative solution. This suspension is used to prepare slides for cytological examination to detect abnormalities or disease. Advantages of Liquid-Based Cytology (LBC): Improved slide preparation: LBC creates a thin-layer or monolayer slide preparation, providing better quality and clarity than conventional Papanicolaou (Pap) smears. Enhanced cell preservation: The collection fluid used in LBC fixes, homogenizes, and rinses the cells, ensuring better preservation for microscopic examination. Reduced sample contamination: The homogenization process minimizes the presence of non-representative material, such as blood or mucus, leading to a more accurate analysis of the collected cells. Increased diagnostic accuracy: With improved sample quality, LBC enhances the sensitivity and specificity of cervical cancer screening, allowing for more reliable detection of abnormalities. Disadvantage: Although cervical cytological screening has proven effective in reducing the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer, the conventional Pap test is less sensitive than commonly thought. The false-negative rate of the conventional Pap test has been reported to reach as high as 50%. Reference: https://www.gfmer.ch/GFMER_members/pdf/Liquid-based-cytology-Abd-El-Hafez-2010.pdf

questions.question: Which of the following is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Eosin B Explanation: Eosin B is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain. Eosin is a different type of stain typically used for general histology to highlight cytoplasm in tissues, but it is not used in the Papanicolaou (Pap) stain. The Papanicolaou (Pap) stain is a widely used technique for examining cells from the cervix to screen for cervical cancer and other abnormalities. It uses a combination of multiple dyes to differentiate cellular components: Hematoxylin - Stains the cell nuclei, allowing for clear visualization of nuclear structure. Orange G - Stains keratinized cells orange, highlighting squamous cells. Eosin A - Second counterstain & a polychrome mixture of Eosin Y and Light Green (stains cytoplasm and helps differentiate between various cell types). Reference: Bancroftâs Theory and Practice of Histological Techniques, 8th Edition, Page 132

questions.question: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.explanation: site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor is the mediastinum. Extragonadal germ cell tumors can be benign or malignant. Benign extragonadal germ cell tumors are called benign teratomas: These are more common than malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors and are often very large Malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors are divided into two types: Seminoma Non-seminoma Reference: .
